contentrichtext.text: {{italic title}} {{for|the character|Mr. Toad}} {{unreferenced|date=August 2011}} [[Image:toad-of-toad-hall.jpg|thumb|right|Poster for a 2008 theatrical production of ''Toad of Toad Hall'']] '''''Toad of Toad Hall''''' is the first of several dramatisations of [[Kenneth Grahame]]'s 1908 novel ''[[The Wind in the Willows]]''. It was written by [[A. A. Milne]], with [[incidental music]] by [[Harold Fraser-Simson]]. Milne extracted the adventures of [[Mr. Toad]] (which form only about half of the original book) because they lent themselves most easily to being staged. Milne loved Grahame's book, which is one of the reasons he decided to adapt it. The play has four main characters: Rat, Badger, Mole, and Toad. Toad's caravan and car adventures are included, as well as his imprisonment, escape, and subsequent fight with the weasels and stoats to regain his home with the help of his friends. Although not a musical, the play contains six songs. Its first production was at the [[Lyric Theatre (London)|Lyric Theatre]] in [[London]] on 17 December 1929. In season 2, episode 2 of ''[[Downton Abbey]]'', the dowager countess says to Lady Edith Crawley, "You're not Toad of Toad Hall!," after Lady Edith announces at dinner that she has volunteered to operate a tractor at a nearby farm because the men who normally operate it are away fighting in World War One. ==Actors== During the play's history many actors have played the part of Toad in a number of plays, films, and TV dramatizations. These include: * [[Alan Reid (actor)|Alan Reid]] - [[BBC]] Television Play in 1946. Co-starred with [[Kenneth More]] as Badger and [[Jon Pertwee]] as the judge in the same adaption. * [[Terry Jones]] – Director and actor in the film, ''[[The Wind in the Willows (1996 film)|The Wind in the Willows]]'' * [[Leo McKern]] – as Toad on stage in [[London]] * [[Michael Hordern]] – at the Shakespeare Memorial (now the Royal Shakespeare) Theatre, Stratford * [[David Jason]] – for the best known animation, for Cosgrove-Hall * [[Hugh Laurie]] – for another animation * [[Rik Mayall]] – for a TV animation * [[Griff Rhys-Jones]] – in the West End * [[Matt Lucas]] – for the BBC live action adaptation * Eric Blore – in the Disney short * Raymond Westwell – at Stratford *[[Patrick Wymark]] – at Stratford *[[Gerald Campion]] – on television, and in London * [[James Hayter (actor)|James Hayter]] – on television * Jeremy Geidt – in London * [[Peter Woodthorpe]] – in London and at Stratford * Martin Friend – in London * [[Ian Wallace (singer)|Ian Wallace]] – in London * Michael Graham Cox – in London * Derek Smith – in London, at Stratford and on radio * [[Michael Bates (actor)|Michael Bates]] – in London * [[Jeremy Sinden]] – [[Old Vic]], London * [[Nicky Henson]] – in London * Ian Talbot – in London * Peter Sowerbutts – in Bromley, Kent * Dale Superville – in Salisbury * [[Michael Williams (actor)|Michael Williams]] – Stratford * David Philip-Harcombe Boyle – Thame == External links == * [http://www.mckellen.com/stage/00119.htm Toad of Toad Hall 1961–62 production], with a [http://www.mckellen.com/stage/00119c.htm cast] including [[Ian McKellen]] {{The Wind in the Willows}} [[Category:Plays by A.
